The foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in mathematics. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. The approach is based on a set of axioms that guarantee that a category is equivalent to that of continuous linear functions between Hilbert spaces. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This approach addresses a question about the foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. The approach is also relevant to the foundations of mathematics in general.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause disease in a variety of hosts. The evolutionary origin of the myxozoan body plan, which is characterized by a distinctive structure, the polar capsule, is unknown. Here, we present the first genomic and transcriptomic analyses of two myxozoan species, which represent the most distant lineages in the group. Our results show that myxozoans are cnidarians and are a sister group to the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our analyses also reveal that myxozoans have one of the smallest reported animal genomes and that they have lost many genes involved in signaling and cell–cell communication. These results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. (Show more)

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The virus is able to evade the host immune response by blocking the action of the interferon (IFN) system. In this study, we show that the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein Orf6 is able to block nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key components of the IFN signaling pathway. We found that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and interacts with the Nup98-Rae1 complex to impair nuclear import of cargo proteins. Our data reveal a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune response and may lead to the development of new strategies to combat the pandemic. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. Sperm cells are quiescent in the male reproductive system due to Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels, but become active once introduced into the low-Zn2+-concentration environment of the female reproductive tract. How Zn2+ inhibits proton channels is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. Climate change will affect the productivity of the world’s major crops, but the magnitude of the effects is uncertain. We use global datasets of maize production and climate variability combined with future temperature projections to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that as the global mean temperature increases, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields increases almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. For the top four maize-exporting countries, which account for 87% of global maize exports, the probability that they have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of quantifying diet composition at the species level. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet composition for seven species of large herbivores in a semiarid African savanna. We found that the proportion of grass in the diet varied widely among species, from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers. Grass consumption was highly correlated with stable isotope estimates of grass consumption, indicating that RRA is a reliable quantitative measure of diet. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, but dietary composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages, and that large herbivore diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses expect the crisis to last for many months, and they anticipate problems accessing the CARES Act loans.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of pollution in the ocean. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is far less than expected, on the order of tens of thousands of tons. This is due to the size-selective sinks of plastic debris in the ocean interior, which are not accounted for in the current models. This sink is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The history of the Sun and the Solar System is recorded in the composition of presolar grains, which are formed in the cores of stars. We determined the ages of 40 presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga, which are consistent with the formation of the Solar System. A majority of the grains have ages of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This indicates that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago, which possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. Longer lifetimes are expected for large grains. We estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This study provides a new constraint on the formation of the Sun and the Solar System.

We provide a comprehensive picture of the evolution of the global fishing fleet, its fishing effort, and the effective catch per unit of effort (CPUE) since the 1950s. We show that the global fleet has doubled in size since the 1950s, with the motorized fleet expanding rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased since the 1950s, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. We also show that the effective CPUE of the global fleet has decreased by a fifth since 1950, but this is not the case for all countries. We conclude that the global fleet is likely to continue to expand, but that the effective CPUE of the global fleet is likely to stabilize or even decrease in the coming decades. This will be a challenge for sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the amount of energy available to the mother is a key factor in the evolution of sociality. Here, we show that the evolution of sociality can be understood in terms of the evolution of the mother’s ability to increase the amount of energy available to her offspring.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects multiple brain regions. The disease is characterized by the presence of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. In this study, we show that the inflammatory protease caspase-1 is able to cleave the C terminus of α-syn, leading to its aggregation. We also show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. Finally, we show that VX-765 is able to limit the neurodegenerative process in this mouse model. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to slow down the progression of MSA. This would be of great importance, as no treatment is currently available to slow down the aggressive neurodegenerative process in MSA. This study also provides a proof of concept for the use of VX-765 in a mouse model of MSA. This study opens the door to the use of VX-765 in clinical trials in MSA patients.

The endothelium is the single layer of cells that lines all blood vessels. It is the primary interface between the circulatory system and the tissues of the body. The endothelium controls vascular function, including the control of blood pressure, the regulation of inflammation, and the control of the exchange of oxygen and nutrients between blood and tissue. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to process and integrate information from multiple sources. Here, we show that the endothelium is organized into a network of cells that is highly connected and that the communication between cells is short-ranged and fast. These findings provide insights into the design of the endothelium and its role in the control of cardiovascular function.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. In this paper, we describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on the pandemic, including both traditional public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the body. They are involved in a wide variety of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate, blood pressure, and breathing. They are also involved in pathological processes, such as epilepsy, cardiac arrhythmia, and muscle spasms. Inactivation of these channels is crucial for the control of their function. We have identified a key residue in the activation gate of potassium channels that is involved in the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. This allosteric communication is crucial for the control of the channel’s function.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical to the health of the host. The composition of the gut microbiome is influenced by the host, the diet, and the gut microbiota itself. The gut microbiota is also a source of natural products, which are compounds that are produced by microorganisms and have a wide range of potential applications. This study provides evidence that anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome produce natural products, which could be used to develop new therapeutics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the mechanisms underlying the establishment of social hierarchies remain largely unknown. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with the risk of becoming subordinate, directly influences social dominance in rats. We further identify a key role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens, a brain region that is involved in the regulation of social behavior. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This paper presents a digital synthesis approach to design and manufacture multifunctional structures that can realize any prescribed mechanical response under large deformation. The proposed approach is based on the digital synthesis of composite structures with multiple material phases, which are digitally designed to have distinct behaviors. The synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, and their highly nonlinear responses are physically realized. The synthesized structures are highly programmable and can be assembled into architectures to achieve highly complex and navigable responses. The proposed approach can be utilized to design multifunctional structures with specific mechanical behaviors for a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a major regulator of the oxygen carrying capacity of the blood. The expression of the hemoglobin genes is regulated by a variety of factors, including the circadian clock. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key regulator of the expression of the hemoglobin genes in human erythroid tissues. IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal liver and is down-regulated in the adult bone marrow. In addition, IGF2BP1 is expressed in erythroid cells in the adult, but its expression is restricted to the gamma-globin gene locus in the fetal liver. These findings suggest that IGF2BP1 is a key regulator of the expression of the fetal hemoglobin genes in the human fetal liver. This is the first demonstration of a role for IGF2BP1 in the regulation of the expression of the hemoglobin genes. These findings have implications for the understanding of the regulation of the hemoglobin system in humans. (Show more)

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide. Despite recent advances in treatment, the majority of patients do not respond to current therapies. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, which is highly relevant to cancer. We found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which is highly frequent in cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance. This resistance is mediated by the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. We also found that inhibition of SREBP1 or the fatty acid desaturase, stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), which is a transcriptional target of SREBP1, sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis. These findings suggest that combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. However, the use of these drugs is associated with the development of heart failure. This study provides a mechanism of action of these drugs, which may help to improve the safety of their use.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older forest bird populations, but that the policy has not yet been effective in reversing the decline of older forest bird populations. We also show that the NWFP has not been effective in halting the decline of early-seral bird populations. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our findings also highlight the importance of monitoring and adaptive management in the context of policy.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This study shows that exposure to electronic devices in the hours before bedtime can have important effects on sleep. Specifically, exposure to light-emitting devices in the evening phase-delays the circadian clock, suppresses melatonin, and reduces alertness the following morning. These effects are likely due to the short-wavelength–enriched light emitted by these devices, which has been shown experimentally to produce alerting effects, suppress melatonin, and phase-shift the biological clock. This study demonstrates the importance of the timing of exposure to electronic devices and the need for further research on the effects of these devices on sleep and health.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a short-term cooling that occurred at ∼12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) in these samples is from the Earth. In contrast, the YDB site in Pennsylvania is remarkable in yielding 2- to 5-mm diameter spherules containing minerals such as suessite (Fe-Ni silicide) that form at temperatures in excess of 2000 °C.

The role of CTLA-4 in the regulation of autoimmunity has been extensively studied, but the specific contribution of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity in the adult mouse is still unclear. Here, we show that the deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice results in the development of a variety of autoinflammatory diseases, which are not observed in congenital deficiency. This indicates that the role of CTLA-4 in the regulation of autoimmunity is not limited to the development of autoimmunity in the early life, but also in the adult. This study provides a better understanding of the role of CTLA-4 in the regulation of autoimmunity. It also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of autoinflammatory diseases. Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 beetle genomes and transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose, the major component of plant cell walls. Our results suggest that the first appearance of these genes may have triggered a Mesozoic diversification of specialized plant-feeding beetles. This diversification was driven by convergent evolution of symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls, which resulted in nearly half of all living beetle species. These results highlight the importance of plant cell wall-degrading enzymes in the evolution of beetles and the role of symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls in the diversification of beetles. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that is highly dependent on APOE isoform. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis is testable in future studies.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the mantle by a sharp boundary. It is the only solid core in the solar system. The formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. The nucleation mechanism of the inner core is one of the most important issues. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still unclear. In this study, we found that the nucleation of the inner core is different from that of the outer core.

This study provides evidence that the brain DA responses to methylphenidate are reduced in marijuana abusers, who are at high risk for addiction. The findings are consistent with the hypothesis that the blunted responses to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers are due to decreased brain reactivity to the DA stimulation, which might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. The study also highlights the need to investigate the effects of chronic marijuana on the brain DA system.

Language is the defining cognitive skill of the human species. Despite its importance, the human brain’s mechanisms for comprehending language are only just beginning to be understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks can be used to understand the human brain’s responses to language. Our results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. We show that this instability is due to the fact that many of the problems that DL is solving are ill-conditioned. We introduce a new class of algorithms that are stable in the limit of infinite data, and we prove that they are stable in practice. This is a major advance in the field of machine learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a scientific scandal. The scientific community has been slow to recognize the many ways in which the pandemic is a result of the scientific community’s own failures. This article is a call to action for scientists to recognize the many ways in which the pandemic is a result of the scientific community’s own failures.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which cause infection of the peripheral nerves and the central nervous system, respectively. This study provides the first genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, which is associated with diffuse lepromatous leprosy and Lucio's phenomenon. The genome sequence reveals that M. lepromatosis is closely related to the ancient MRCA of the leprosy bacteria, and that it has retained the ability to infect the peripheral nervous system. This study also provides evidence that the two leprosy bacteria have been conserved despite their ancient separation. This study has implications for understanding the evolution of leprosy and for the development of new therapies. (Show more)

Entanglement and entropy are key concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also fundamental to the understanding of thermodynamics, which is the study of the macroscopic properties of isolated systems. However, the study of the evolution of entanglement and entropy in isolated quantum systems is a very challenging task. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This result is checked for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has killed millions of people worldwide. The only available vaccine is based on the inactivated virus, which is not suitable for mass vaccination. Here, we describe a live attenuated virus vaccine, COVI-VAC, that is highly protective against COVID-19 in a relevant animal model. This vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro, but grows robustly at the permissive temperature, which is suitable for large-scale manufacturing. The vaccine is also highly attenuated, resulting in mild disease and low lung pathology. The vaccine is expected to be suitable for mass vaccination programs. This is a major advance in the fight against COVID-19. (Show more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) was characterized by high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown. Here, we present a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of human-to-human transmission in the history of plague.

The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of neuroscience. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is less understood. Here, we show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the evolution of brain information-processing capacity. We show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is also affected by the evolution of the number of neurons.

TRAP1 is a molecular chaperone that is found predominantly in mitochondria. It is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, current inhibitors cannot distinguish between TRAP1 and HSP90, making their utility as probes of TRAP1-specific function questionable. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin is a key regulator of actin dynamics. It is involved in a variety of processes, including cell motility, cell division, and cytokinesis. However, the molecular mechanism of ADF/cofilin action is not well understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin is able to sever actin filaments in a mechanical context, which is relevant to cells. We find that ADF/cofilin is able to sever filaments that are connected by other filaments, which is not the case for filaments that are not connected. We propose that this is due to the mechanical torque that is generated by the connection of filaments. This torque is critical to boost the severing rate of ADF/cofilin. We believe that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. This mechanism may be important for other proteins that are involved in severing highly connected filament networks.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other beverages. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and food intake. They also have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on the development of obesity.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its history. It is the only island in the world that is both a biodiversity hotspot and a country. However, its history is still debated. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity (including maternal lineages, paternal lineages, and genome-wide data) across 257 villages and 2,704 Malagasy individuals. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. We show that the amount of positive and negative content in a person’s Facebook News Feed influences the emotions of others. This work has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in social networks, and for the design of social media platforms.

The presence of RNA modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) has been shown to impact protein synthesis. However, the impact of a single modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in the mRNA has not been studied. Here, we show that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA can have a significant impact on protein synthesis. This study provides a foundation for understanding the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis. (Show more)

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in biology. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This attractor is consistent with energetic constraints on the evolution of body size in the aquatic realm.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The temperature at which rhinovirus replicates most efficiently in the nasal cavity is unknown. We show that rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperature of the nasal cavity than at the core body temperature. This temperature-dependent growth is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of vaccines and antiviral therapies for the common cold. (Show more)

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense the environment and respond appropriately. Here we show that the type IV pili of Pseudomonas aeruginosa are used as a sensor to regulate surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This is the first example of a bacterial type IV pili being used as a sensor.

This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global risk of pesticide contamination of surface water. We show that, despite the existence of legally accepted regulatory threshold levels, the presence of pesticides in surface water is very common, and that the concentrations of these pesticides are often high enough to cause harm to aquatic organisms. This study also shows that the risk of pesticide contamination of surface water is higher for newer-generation insecticides, higher in larger catchments, and higher in countries with less stringent environmental regulations. These results suggest that the current regulatory system is not effective in protecting surface water from the effects of agricultural pesticides. Thus, there is a need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices. This study also highlights the need for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

This study provides evidence of the circulation of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, a species that is a major reservoir of the virus in North America. This discovery has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. Our findings highlight the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This approach is critical to prevent the emergence of new, more virulent variants and to mitigate the risk of future pandemics.

This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a global public health crisis. The disease is believed to be caused by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau in the brain, but the mechanisms underlying this accumulation are not fully understood. Here, we show that neurons, which are the primary cell type in the brain, are capable of producing a variety of proinflammatory factors, which may contribute to the accumulation of Aβ and tau. This study provides a potential new target for the development of treatments for AD.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still debated. This study presents the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in the archaeological record.

We have developed a method to study the folding of large proteins in real time. This method, which is based on the use of hydrogen exchange, has allowed us to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a large protein that is known to fold through a native-like intermediate. The results show that the intermediate is an obligatory step on the folding pathway and that the protein folds in more than one step. This study adds a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. (Show more)

In this paper, we describe a mechanism for the decapping of RNA that is distinct from the one used by the predominant decapping enzyme in bacteria. This enzyme, ApaH, uses the same active site for decapping as it does for capping, and it is inactivated by the conditions that enable accumulation of the cap-removing RNA pyrophosphohydrolase, RppH. We show that RppH decaps capped RNA by a mechanism that is different from the one it uses to decaps other RNA termini. This mechanism is unique in the bacterial world, and it has important implications for the regulation of gene expression in response to stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a major cause of death worldwide. Although the immune response is essential for the resolution of infection, it can also lead to severe tissue damage and organ failure. We have shown that arginine, an essential amino acid, is depleted in sepsis and that this depletion is associated with the development of myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) and regulatory T cells (Tregs). We have also shown that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is increased in sepsis and that this increase is associated with the restoration of T cell function. These results provide evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides evidence for the use of citrulline as a potential therapeutic strategy for the treatment of sepsis. View Full-Text

The biomass of all living organisms is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. These results provide a global perspective on the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. This information is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a system, when perturbed, returns to a state of criticality, in which it evolves at a rate proportional to its current activity. SOC is observed in a variety of natural and artificial systems, including earthquakes, firestorms, sandpiles, neural networks, and financial markets. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for quantum computing, but its electronic properties are not fully understood. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its electronic properties can be tuned reversibly by strain engineering. This opens up new opportunities for tailoring the electronic properties of diamond for quantum applications.

This study provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of a class of plant-specific peptides, which are expressed in nodules of the model legume Medicago truncatula. The structure of the 36-amino acid peptide NCR044 was solved by NMR spectroscopy. This structure was largely disordered and highly dynamic, with one four-residue α-helix and one three-residue antiparallel β-sheet stabilized by two disulfide bonds. NCR044 peptide exhibited potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens, including Botrytis cinerea and three Fusarium spp. It inhibited germination in quiescent spores of B. cinerea. In germlings, it breached the fungal plasma membrane and induced reactive oxygen species. It bound to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro. Time-lapse confocal and superresolution microscopy revealed strong fungal cell wall binding, penetration of the cell membrane at discrete foci, followed by gradual loss of turgor, subsequent accumulation in the cytoplasm, and elevated levels in nucleoli of germlings. This work illustrates the antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide against plant fungal pathogens and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction, and the extent of molecular continuity between the sexes is largely unknown. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm is modified by the female reproductive tract, and that this modification supports sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work also provides a resource for future studies of the molecular basis of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, helping to prevent bleeding. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application to VWF switches the protein to a second state with faster binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD, and may be used to treat bleeding.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been shown to influence health and disease. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study. This study is a comprehensive analysis of the human virome, and provides a resource for future studies. The data are available in a public database, and the analysis methods are described in detail. The results of the analysis are also available, and include a list of virus–disease associations.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI process. The HSRL is able to simultaneously measure aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature history of the Earth is a key factor in understanding the evolution of life. This study provides a new method for reconstructing the temperature history of the Earth, using the thermostability of ancestral enzymes. The results are consistent with previous interpretations based on isotopic evidence, and provide a new way to understand the evolution of life on Earth.

Ion channels are the key regulators of ion flow in the body. They are also the targets of many drugs. The activation and inactivation of ion channels are important for the control of the body’s functions. In this study, we found that the activation and inactivation of the large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel are state-dependent. This finding provides a new perspective for the study of the activation and inactivation of ion channels. It also provides a new approach for the development of drugs for the treatment of diseases caused by ion channel dysfunction. (Show more)

Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The parasite, Plasmodium, invades the human red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle. The invasion process is a complex event that requires the interaction of multiple parasite proteins with the RBC surface. Here, we show that one of these proteins, EBA175, alters the physical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding suggests that the malaria parasite primes the RBC surface, altering the physical properties of the target cell, and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This would constitute a major change in our understanding of malaria parasite invasion. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for quantum computing, but its electronic properties are not fully understood. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its electronic properties can be tuned reversibly by strain engineering. This opens up new opportunities for the study of the relationship between the electronic and mechanical properties of diamond, and for the design of new devices.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza virus outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have important implications for understanding the impact of climate change on influenza virus transmission and disease outcome. They also provide a mechanistic understanding of the impact of dry air on host defense and disease outcome, which may be useful for the development of new

The brain is thought to parse incoming language into a tree-like structure of nested phrases. However, whether and how the brain builds such structures remains largely unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity, providing evidence for a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based solely on sequential transition probability over lexical and syntactic categories, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Formal model comparison indicated that the model of multiword phrase construction provided a better fit than probability-based models at most sites in superior temporal and inferior frontal cortices. Activity in those regions was consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases.

Axin is a key component of the canonical Wnt pathway, which is involved in the development of the nervous system and the immune system. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation is likely to be important for the tissue-specific regulation of the two forms of Axin.

This study provides a detailed characterization of a brain circuit that may contribute to the development of obesity. The lateral hypothalamus is a brain region that is involved in the regulation of feeding. Electrical stimulation of this region causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We found that this circuit is involved in the development of overeating, as lesions of this circuit blocked the development of this circuit. This circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety, suggesting that it is not involved in the development of normal feeding behavior.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria is a key component of sustainable agriculture. Here, we have developed a system for the plant-controlled regulation of nitrogen fixation in bacteria. This system is based on the production of a signaling molecule by the plant, which is taken up by the bacteria and used to control gene expression. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to improve the efficiency of nitrogen fixation in agriculture, and it could also be used to control nitrogen fixation in other systems, such as in the bioenergy crops that are used for biofuel production. This work could also lead to the development of new strategies for the control of nitrogen fixation in the environment.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Data from monitoring records and community surveys provide evidence about how the program may affect forest outcomes. Community members perceived that the program’s monitors were new authorities with influence over forest management and that the monitors’ incentivized patrols were substitutes for traditional, unincentivized citizen patrols that suffer from free riding and inhibit timely community detection of and responses to deforestation. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

We show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius has a unique way of outsourcing its hearing function to its web. The spider’s web is a self-manufactured, protein-based acoustic antenna that is able to detect the motion of the air particles caused by sound. The spider can remotely sense the direction and location of the sound source, and it can also adjust the size of the acoustic antenna to meet its needs. This study provides a unique way of outsourcing hearing function, which is of great interest to the study of extended and regenerative sensing, and it also provides a new idea for the design of acoustic flow detectors. (Show more)

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein is the target for the development of vaccines against COVID-19. However, the production of vaccines based on the RBD is challenging due to the low expression level and instability of the protein. Here, we report the design and construction of a variant of the RBD that is more stable and can be expressed at high levels in bacteria. The variant protein is able to induce high-affinity antibodies in mice, and the resulting antibodies are able to neutralize two variants of concern. The engineered RBD can be used to construct a virus-like particle (VLP) vaccine, which is able to protect hamsters from viral challenge. These results provide a promising approach for the development of vaccines against COVID-19. (Show more)

Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor in infants. Although the majority of neuroblastoma patients is cured by surgery and chemotherapy, the disease is still incurable in a significant number of patients. In this study, we show that the ALK receptor is activated in a significant number of neuroblastoma patients. We also show that the ALK receptor is activated in zebrafish and that the ALK receptor is involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. Our results provide a better understanding of the mechanisms of neuroblastoma development and may lead to the development of new therapies.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it has been a constant threat to humans for millennia. This study provides a comprehensive view of the evolution of plague during its formative years, from the time it emerged from its ancestral form to the time it was adapted to the flea. Our results show that the plague lineage that gave rise to the plague pathogen was nonflea-adapted and likely extinct by the time of the Bronze Age. This study also reveals the rapid spread of the plague pathogen across Eurasia, which may have been facilitated by the spread of the flea. These findings provide insights into the early evolution of plague and its adaptation to its vector. (Show more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump. We found that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. This work has implications for understanding the political and social consequences of the endorsement of HM.

The soil organic carbon (SOC) stock in agricultural soils has been increasing in recent decades, but the extent to which this is due to agricultural management practices is unclear. We show that soil health management practices, such as reduced tillage, diversified crop rotations, and manure addition, can increase SOC storage in the top 1 m of soil. These practices also increase the amount of SOC stored in the mineral fraction of soil, which is important because this fraction is more resistant to decomposition. These results highlight the potential of soil health management practices to increase the amount of SOC stored in agricultural soils. This is especially important because the amount of SOC stored in agricultural soils is currently increasing at a rate of 1% per year, which is not keeping pace with the rate of global SOC loss. Our results also highlight the importance of integrating livestock and perennial grasslands into agricultural systems to increase SOC storage. These results are important for understanding the role of agriculture in global carbon cycles and for developing strategies to mitigate climate change.

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify host, viral, and environmental risk factors contributing to zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This resource can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. Nectar is the reward that most plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of this reward is often an important factor in attracting pollinators. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of the blood-red plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify a similar red nectar in the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae. This work demonstrates that the red color of nectar is a convergently evolved trait, and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a new alkaloid with potential pharmaceutical applications. (Show more)

We present a case study of a female individual from the Early Medieval period in Europe. We show that she had a genetic ancestry that was not present in modern Europeans, and that she also had a genetic ancestry that was not present in the ancestors of modern Europeans. This is an example of a female-biased migration, which is a rare phenomenon in the literature. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings are important for understanding the origin and evolution of MERS-CoV and for developing strategies to prevent future MERS outbreaks. This article is protected by copyright.

This study demonstrates the utility of a cloud-based, pathogen-agnostic metagenomic approach for the detection of undifferentiated febrile illness in resource-scarce settings. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which was detected in a patient before the national outbreak. This study highlights the importance of pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings, where outbreaks are likely to emerge, but where laboratory diagnostics and bioinformatics capacity are limited. Coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens, and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be used to detect emerging pathogens in other resource-scarce settings. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The human genome is replicated in a complex process that involves the replication of the lagging strand template and the formation of the DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) holoenzyme. The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. Here, we report the results of a series of kinetic analyses that provide a detailed understanding of the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that pol δ maintains a loose association with the proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) sliding clamp while replicating DNA and that this association is transient, promoting the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. These results have profound implications for the replication of the human genome.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in science. In this paper, we describe the first in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can replicate RNA from an RNA template. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

COVID-19 is a severe disease with high mortality. The treatment is still in the stage of clinical trial. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which is used for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, is effective in the treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It can reduce the mortality and improve the clinical symptoms. This study provides a new idea for the treatment of COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage to cells. The ability of fungi to regulate copper homeostasis is well established, but the existence of copper-binding natural products in fungi is unknown. Here we report the discovery of a copper-binding natural product in Aspergillus fumigatus, a human fungal pathogen. This discovery has implications for our understanding of the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the interactions of fungi with other microbes. This work also provides a model for the discovery of natural products that bind toxic metals. (Read more)

The presence of tridymite, a high-temperature, high-pressure polymorph of silica, in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a product of high-temperature, high-pressure metamorphism. The presence of this mineral in a sedimentary rock is even more significant because it is cogenetic with other sedimentary minerals, suggesting that it was deposited in a sedimentary environment.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agriculture, and the frequency of late-spring frosts is increasing in many regions. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is determined by the evolutionary history of the species involved, and that this history is in turn determined by the climate of the region. Our findings can be used to inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are critical for the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the mechanisms by which they contribute to disease are not well understood. Here, we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, we found that Th17 cells could provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease mechanism is not fully understood. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. This will enable the study of disease mechanisms and the development of new therapies. This method will also enable the study of the disease mechanism in other neurodegenerative diseases. This study provides a mechanism for how pathogens can influence the composition of the arthropod microbiota to facilitate infection. The findings also provide a potential target for the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases.

This paper describes a new species of early bird, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This species adds to our understanding of the evolution of the avian tail, which has been a major focus of research in recent years.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. This color diversity is due to the presence of chromophores in the proteins that make up the animal. However, some vertebrates have distinctive blue-green colors, which are due to the presence of biliverdin, a compound that is not normally present in vertebrates. We show that this phenomenon has evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of anurans (frogs and toads), and that it is due to the presence of a group of proteins that bind biliverdin. These proteins are most similar to human antitrypsin, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study provides a molecular basis for the evolution of green color in vertebrates. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Hypoxia is a feature of many solid tumors, including breast cancer, and is associated with the development of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and metastasis. We show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates N6-methyladenosine (m6A) residues in mRNA. ALKBH5 expression is increased in breast cancer, and ALKBH5-deficient mice are protected from tumor development. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia in a HIF-dependent manner, and ALKBH5 expression is required for the development of breast cancer stem cells. Thus, ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia in breast cancer, and its expression is required for the development of breast cancer stem cells. These findings may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of breast cancer. (Show more)

The use of fetal animal skins in the production of parchment is a long-standing controversy. This paper presents a method to determine the origin of the animal skins used in the production of parchment. The method is based on the use of a simple, noninvasive, and objective technique to extract proteins from the parchment surface. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. (Abridged)

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is still debated, but the evidence points to a combination of factors. We present a precise age model for the extinction and recovery, which will allow a more refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. This will also allow a more precise evaluation of the ability of the ecosystem to recover from the extinction.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in various biological processes, including metabolism, cancer, and the circadian rhythm. However, the function of RORα in the intestine is still unclear. Here, we report that RORα is essential for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also find that RORα-deficient mice are susceptible to intestinal inflammation. Our findings provide insights into the role of RORα in intestinal homeostasis and inflammation. These results also suggest that RORα could be a potential target for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system and for vaccine development. We have determined the structure of the spike protein in the D614G mutant form, which is the most prevalent in circulation. We find that the D614G mutant spike is more open than the wild-type spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and facilitate fusion with the target membrane. These results provide insights into the mechanism of the D614G mutation and may help to inform the development of vaccines and antiviral therapies. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, reflecting persistent structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry, and they are also of great interest in other fields, such as physics, biology, and geology. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we discover that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt are electron acceptors, while the elements right after them are electron donors. Our results are of fundamental importance in chemistry and are also of great interest in other fields.

We show that human demography, rather than climate change, is the main driver of changes in global fire activity. This has important implications for the global carbon cycle, as well as for the role of fire in climate change. Our results suggest that, in the absence of fire suppression, global warming could be reduced by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. However, our results also show that, in some regions, fire activity may become more extreme, increasing the risk of more severe wildfires. Our study highlights the importance of fire in climate change, and the need to better understand the role of fire in climate change.

This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbioses, which are among the most important interactions in nature. We show that the provision of a single nutrient, chitin, by the host to its symbiont, V. fischeri, is a key factor in the maintenance of the mutualism. This is the first time that a single nutrient has been shown to be critical for the maintenance of a symbiosis.

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify topics in the narratives of the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. We show that the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics were the cause of repeated reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague, which is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. It also provides a new perspective on the history of the climate–plague relationship. View Full-Text

This study provides evidence that a densovirus is the cause of the asteroid wasting disease (SSWD) that has been observed on the Pacific Coast of North America. The study also provides evidence that the virus has been present on the coast for at least 72 y. This is the first report of a densovirus causing a mass mortality of sea stars.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis of patients with AML is poor. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies for AML, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that an antibody targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is effective in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that the observed therapeutic effects are dependent on effector-cell–mediated killing and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. We also show that the antibody can suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach could be used to treat other types of cancer as well. Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity, its history, and its culture. It is therefore of great interest to understand the history of the settlement of Madagascar. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, which allowed us to study the history of the settlement of Madagascar from a genomic perspective. We find that Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its genomic diversity, with a recent history of admixture and a strong influence of geography on the present genomic diversity. These results provide insights into the history of the settlement of Madagascar. They also provide a framework for the study of the genomic diversity of other island populations.
