Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a protein that interacts with glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and increases dehydrogenase activity. This protein also interferes with the ability of a regulatory RNA to repress carbon utilization genes. These results demonstrate that the protein and RNA compete for the same binding sites and that the protein can have multiple functions. This is an example of a protein that is not considered to be “coding” but has a role in regulating the expression of genes. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. View Full-Text

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status, but their data is often not used in agricultural decision-making. We show that the USDA Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey, which is conducted by a large number of crop experts across the US, can be used to monitor crop status and predict crop yields. We show that the CPC is a robust indicator of crop status, and that it can be used to monitor crop status and predict crop yields. We also show that the CPC is a powerful source of information for monitoring crop status, and can be used to provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. This work demonstrates the potential of the CPC to provide a more complete picture of agricultural production, and to improve the accuracy of agricultural decision-making.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that involves the ability to integrate and store information in working memory. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of single neurons. We show that this mechanism can support memory on a variety of timescales, from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. In this study, we present the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key component of the evolution of photosynthesis and the origin of the plant lineage. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major event in the evolution of plastids. Here, we show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle is linked to a relaxation of selection on the plastid genome, which is accompanied by a stepwise reduction in gene function. Our findings provide a molecular basis for the evolution of the plastid genome and its role in the origin of the plant lineage. They also provide a framework for understanding the evolution of the plastid genome in the context of the evolution of the plant lineage. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was the worst in the last century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of this event by a factor of five to six. This increase in drought risk is expected to increase further under high-emission scenarios. This study highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the conditions under which they are formed are still not fully understood. This study demonstrates that the conditions for the formation of quasicrystals are not as extreme as previously thought, and that they can be found in the history of our civilization.

The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring in (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is a key step in the biosynthesis of these molecules. The reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, one of which is O2 sensitive, the other O2 dependent. The O2-dependent enzyme is a diiron protein, whereas the O2-sensitive enzyme is an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein. We show that the O2-dependent enzyme is a subunit of the O2-sensitive enzyme, and that different classes of the enzyme exist based on their requirement for an additional subunit. These data delineate three classes of O2-dependent cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. (Abridged)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature of multiple sclerosis (MS), and it is well known to be associated with neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is a complex process that involves multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. Neuroinflammation is known to be associated with neurodegenerative diseases, but the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms remain unknown. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a potential mechanism for the role of ASK1 in neurodegenerative diseases. These findings may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases.

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is due to anthropogenic warming.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. As an alternative approach, extensive efforts have been devoted to identifying the convergence of the targets and functions of the autism-risk genes to facilitate mapping out causal paths. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that the reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a new perspective for understanding the etiology of autism. This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results are consistent with the idea that the news media are driven by a desire to attract and retain audiences, and that this is likely to be at least partly motivated by the tendency for humans to react more strongly to negative than positive information.

Stormorken syndrome is a rare disorder of unknown cause. Here, we report a patient with Stormorken syndrome, a disorder of the Ca2+ release channel, and describe the molecular basis of the disorder. We also provide evidence that the Ca2+ release channel is involved in other conditions. This study advances our understanding of the molecular basis of the Ca2+ release channel, and suggests new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (Show more)

The spreading of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not well understood. Here we show that the spreading of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on the internalization of aggregates by neurons, and that this process is dependent on the activity of the endocytic machinery. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the spreading of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of these diseases. (Show more)

Bats are the most diverse group of mammals, and their saliva is known to be a rich source of immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are largely unknown. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and found that this protein has the potential to inhibit the host immune response and facilitate viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting this protein for the treatment of viral diseases. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of both human serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) isozymes, which is effective in cancer cells. We have also identified a metabolic deficiency of one of the most aggressive types of cancer, diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This deficiency is rooted in defective glycine import, and thus represents a targetable metabolic vulnerability of this cancer. This work provides a metabolic rationale for the treatment of cancer, and a potential strategy for the treatment of lymphoma. It also provides a new class of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins, including SOD1, TDP-43, and FUS, form characteristic inclusions in the brain and spinal cord. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusions are composed of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state is likely a consequence of the unique cellular environment of the motor neuron, which is characterized by a high level of protein aggregation. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state is likely a consequence of the unique cellular environment of the motor neuron. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal is designed to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. The device can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. This work is a step toward the development of a new platform for quantum simulation.

The Cretaceous is often considered to be a time of global cooling and a reduction in plant diversity. However, this study shows that the Cretaceous was a time of great plant diversification, including the origin of aquatic plants.

The evolution of viruses is often studied using sequences from living organisms. However, viruses are often present in ancient remains, and the study of ancient viruses can provide insights into the evolution of viruses and the history of the host. Here we present the genomes of five ancient human parvoviruses, which are associated with a number of conditions, such as arthritis and arthralgias, in adults and fifth disease in children. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Abridged full text)

Sea level is rising around the world, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This paper provides a new estimate of the rate of rise, which is higher than previous estimates. The higher rate of rise is due to the inclusion of data from recent years, which are not well represented in previous estimates.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, pain prevalence has increased with age for each successive birth cohort, and that this increase is larger for those born after 1950. This pattern is not seen for those with a bachelor’s degree, suggesting that the erosion of working-class life is having a negative impact on the health of the next generation.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR to the study of enzymes has been a major advance in this field, but the study of the reaction intermediates that are central to the mechanism of action of many enzymes has been a challenge. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to study the reaction intermediate in a key reaction of tryptophan synthase. This study provides a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of the intermediate, including the location of the hydrogen atoms in the active site, and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This study highlights the power of the integrated application of NMR and X-ray crystallography to the study of enzyme mechanisms. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease with a high mortality rate. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the current standard of care is supportive care. Here, we show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug that is used to treat Ebola virus disease, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS-CoV infection. It may also be considered for the treatment of other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of remdesivir in the treatment of coronavirus infections. It also provides a potential treatment for MERS-CoV, which is a major public health concern. View Full-Text

This study provides a new perspective on the role of host-derived nutrients in the regulation of symbiont populations. We show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiotic partner, a bacterium, is a key factor in the regulation of the symbiont population. This glycan is provided only at night, when the host is quiescent, and its catabolism is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This study also provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the regulation of symbiont populations. We suggest that other hosts may similarly regulate the activities of their symbionts through the strategic provision of specific nutrients, whose catabolism modulates conditions like pH or anoxia in their symbionts’ habitat. This study shows that it is possible to reduce suspension rates in middle schools. This is a major public health problem, and it is also a major contributor to the school–prison pipeline. We show that it is possible to reduce suspension rates by changing the mindset of teachers.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. Assessment for the impact of the EtdT lesions on individual fidelity checkpoints provided further mechanistic insights, where the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Fusion occurs only after S proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. We show that sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, and that the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection. These findings may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

This paper provides evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase the proportion of diners choosing vegetarian meals. This has the potential to contribute to the global effort to reduce the environmental impacts of food production and to improve population health. The results are robust to a range of analyses and are consistent with the idea that nudging can be an effective way to change behavior. The findings have implications for catering managers, policymakers, and researchers interested in the potential of nudging to change behavior.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to engage the extracellular space. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to the surfaceome of a cell line stably expressing six of the most prominent oncogenes, including EGFR, HER2, KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work also provides a resource for the cancer research community. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health crisis. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein that has been proposed to interfere with the immune response. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune suppression and evasion. These findings provide insights into the molecular basis of the COVID-19 pandemic and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats, which is associated with the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, and that CRF acts on the cerebral cortex to trigger the release of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) from astrocytes, leading to cerebral edema. These findings provide a potential mechanism for the development of cerebral edema in hypobaric hypoxia. They also provide a potential target for the treatment of cerebral edema. This study may also have implications for the treatment of other edema-related diseases. (Show more)

The scientific enterprise is based on the idea that we can learn from experience. But what if we have learned from experience that some things are important, and others are not? What if we have learned that some things are important in some circumstances, but not in others? What if we have learned that some things are important, but that the strength of the association is not very strong? In this paper, we describe a way of addressing these questions.

The development of vascular ECs is a critical step in the formation of vascular networks. However, the development of ECs from nonvascular cells has been difficult to achieve. Here, we report the generation of endothelial cells from nonvascular cells using a single transcription factor, Ets variant 2 (ETV2). This study provides a new approach for the generation of vascular ECs, which will be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. In addition, the use of ETV2 as a transcription factor for the generation of vascular ECs will be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. This study will also contribute to the development of vascular networks in regenerative medicine. (Show more)
We report the discovery of a third class of RTKs, augmentor receptors, and demonstrate that they are essential for the development of a specific subset of cells in the body of the zebrafish.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem. Although the molecular mechanisms of T2D are well known, the treatment of T2D is still a challenge. In this study, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function, and its deficiency causes glucose intolerance due to impaired insulin secretion. These findings provide a potential target for the treatment of T2D. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that involves a series of events, including the activation of endothelial cells (ECs). The activation of ECs is associated with the up-regulation of the expression of a series of genes, which are critical for the development of atherosclerotic lesions. However, the mechanisms underlying the activation of ECs are not fully understood. In this study, we found that the activation of ECs is associated with the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ). In addition, we demonstrated that the activation of YAP/TAZ is associated with the disturbed flow, which is a key feature of atheroprone areas. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the activation of ECs and the development of atherosclerotic lesions and may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are correlated with the economic and demographic characteristics of their residents. Specifically, neighborhoods with higher levels of education and higher initial attractiveness are more likely to experience physical improvements. These results are consistent with three classical theories of urban change: the economic theory of human capital, the tipping theory of urban change, and the invasion theory of urban change. Our results provide evidence for the importance of physical appearance in the dynamics of cities and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a class of plant-derived compounds that are used to protect humans and animals from insect bites. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods remain unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel as a receptor of natural repellents, which is absent in mammals. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and it should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of the evolution of arthropod–plant interaction. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is long. We also show that the within-host dynamics of ZIKV are sensitive to the rate of viral production, the rate of viral clearance, and the rate of cell death. We predict that a drug that blocks viral replication can reduce the peak median viral load by ∼3 logs and shorten the time to undetectable median viral load by ∼2 d. These predictions can be used to guide the design of clinical trials. (Show more)

Coral reefs are in the midst of a mass bleaching event, which is pushing them to the brink of collapse. Our understanding of the underlying causes of the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is incomplete. Here, we show that altered nutrient cycling during heat stress is a primary driver of the functional breakdown of the symbiosis. Heat stress increased the metabolic energy demand of the coral host, which was compensated by the catabolic degradation of amino acids. The resulting shift from net uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont subsequently promoted the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Energy limitation and altered symbiotic nutrient cycling are thus key factors in the early heat stress response, directly contributing to the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Interpreting the stability of the coral holobiont in light of its metabolic interactions provides a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general.

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the environment. In the absence of this barrier, the host is susceptible to systemic infections. In this study, we show that the intestinal epithelium is also the primary site of tumorigenesis in Drosophila. We identify a mechanism by which the tumor microenvironment triggers a regenerative response in the epithelium, leading to a loss of the intestinal barrier and dysbiosis of the microbiome. Our findings highlight the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. They also provide a mechanism by which the tumor microenvironment can influence the host immune system to promote its own growth. These findings have implications for understanding the role of the tumor microenvironment in cancer progression and host–microbe interactions. They also provide a potential mechanism for the regulation of host–microbe interactions in other systems.

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond well to it. In this study, we found that the expression of the ROR1 receptor is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also found that ROR1 expression is associated with the expression of genes involved in the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1. These findings suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer.

The start of the last deglaciation is often assumed to be associated with a change in the position of the Southern Hemisphere westerlies. However, this assumption is based on a single proxy record, and the timing of the change is uncertain. We show that a series of massive volcanic eruptions, which are known to cause stratospheric ozone depletion, occurred at the start of the last deglaciation. This coincidence is highly unlikely by chance, and the changes in climate and circulation are consistent with the ozone depletion hypothesis.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security, biodiversity conservation, and fishery sustainability. We find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. Our findings highlight the critical role of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited in aqueous Li-ion batteries. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. Furthermore, hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized with LixNb

In this study, we identify a form of regeneration in the adult nervous system that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of a sensory neuron, and it is enhanced by activating the cAMP signaling pathway. We also show that this form of regeneration is linked to a well-studied form of endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. These findings provide a unique platform for the discovery of genes that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system. In addition, our study suggests that the mammalian CNS may be more plastic than previously thought, and it may be able to regenerate more effectively than previously thought.

The process of recombination is essential for the maintenance of genetic variation in populations. However, the distribution of recombination across the genome is not uniform, and it is unclear whether this variation is a consequence of evolutionary processes or is a consequence of the underlying genome architecture. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus, and compare it to that of other organisms. We find that the distribution of recombination is similar to that of other eukaryotes, suggesting that the evolutionary forces that have shaped the distribution of recombination in other organisms have also shaped the distribution of recombination in Mimulus. This work provides a foundation for understanding the distribution of recombination in plants and other organisms.

The resting state of the brain is a complex, dynamic process that is not well understood. Here, we used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this dominant network was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic resting state network expression in cerebral blood flow scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant resting state network was deactivated during task performance in healthy subjects and early Parkinson’s disease patients. This abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. These results provide a direct measure of the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

This paper describes a new type of RNA modification in eukaryotes, the 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) RNA cap. This modification is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs, and is produced cotranscriptionally. The NAD+ cap is found on pre-mRNAs, and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. This new type of RNA modification could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation alterations at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years in people with diabetes, and that these loci are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study also provides a potential epigenetic mechanism for the beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. This work may also have implications for the understanding of the epigenetic mechanisms of aging.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit flavor is not well understood. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the formation of nitrogenous volatiles from their corresponding precursors. This work provides a major advance in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato fruit flavor, and the identification of this gene will be a valuable resource for the tomato and other fruit industries. We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most profound threats to the functional integrity of the Earth’s ecosystems. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the MEC of freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are essential for spatial navigation, are organized separately from other cell types, and that they are strongly coupled among themselves. These findings provide a detailed view of the organization of the MEC and its functional connections, which will be useful for understanding the function of this region in navigation and other cognitive processes. Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of factors. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not the only flowering regulator in plants. We demonstrate that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the Cuscuta australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-producing neurons of the substantia nigra. The cause of the disease is unknown, but it is thought to be due to a combination of genetic and environmental factors. The disease is progressive and ultimately leads to death. The present study provides evidence that the dopamine-producing neurons are part of a larger system that is affected in the disease. The system is composed of striosomes, a group of neurons in the substantia nigra, and their connections to the striatum, the brain region that receives dopamine projections from the substantia nigra. The striosomes are thought to be involved in the control of mood and motivation. The findings have implications for understanding the disease and for developing treatments.

We are all familiar with the feeling of “clicking” with someone. But how do we know when two people are “clicking”? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that drives the heart. In this study, we found that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN and plays an important role in the function of the SAN. Our findings suggest that STIM1 is a regulator of Ca2+ stores in the SAN and contributes to the automaticity of the SAN. These findings may lead to a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying the function of the SAN and may lead to the development of new therapies for heart failure. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, the function of Si in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is associated with an increase in jasmonic acid (JA) accumulation and defense gene expression. These results suggest that Si may enhance plant resistance against insect herbivores by priming JA-mediated defense responses. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of new strategies for controlling insect pests. (Show more)

This study provides a new perspective on the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in the metabolism of ether lipids, which are important for the function of macrophages. It also provides a new target for the treatment of phenylketonuria.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that involves the ability to integrate and store information in working memory. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of single neurons. We show that this mechanism can support memory on a variety of timescales, including milliseconds, seconds, and even minutes. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

This work is a systematic assessment of DNA nanostructures for their ability to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall of plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are the key design parameters that determine the internalization efficiency of the DNA nanostructure into plant cells. We also show that the internalization efficiency of DNA nanostructures correlates with their respective gene silencing efficiencies but that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment location of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a significant step toward the development of DNA nanostructures as a tool for plant biology.

Eutrophication is one of the greatest threats to the health of aquatic ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient loading to lakes is from nonpoint sources, such as agricultural fields and urban areas. However, the majority of the country’s lakes are connected to large rivers, and the nutrient loads from these rivers are often dominated by a small number of large tributaries. We show that the nutrient loads from small tributaries are often high for their size, and that these nutrients are more likely to be in the form of dissolved inorganic nutrients, which are more bioavailable to algae. This work highlights the importance of small tributaries in driving coastal eutrophication in large water bodies.

We study the dynamics of a chemical network in the presence of a strong environmental forcing. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is a consequence of the interplay between the dynamics of the network and the environment, and it is not present in simpler models.

This paper offers a new perspective on the mechanisms of action of NMDAR-Abs, which are believed to disrupt receptor function. We show that NMDAR-Abs can change the dynamics of the cortical microcircuit, which in turn can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This work offers a new understanding of the mechanisms of action of NMDAR-Abs, which may help to improve the treatment of this disease.

This study provides a new perspective on the history of carbon (C) perturbation events throughout Earth’s history. The study also provides a new understanding of the role of organic matter in the Earth system and the impact of global warming on the ocean.

Certification of palm oil production is a major effort to reduce deforestation. However, the impact of certification on deforestation and fire remains unclear. We use a comprehensive dataset of oil palm plantations in Indonesia to evaluate the impact of certification on deforestation and fire. We find that certification reduced deforestation by 33% from a counterfactual of 9.8 to 6.6% y−1. Nevertheless, most plantations contained little residual forest when they received certification. As a result, certified areas held less than 1% of forests remaining within Indonesian oil palm plantations in 2015. Certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. This study highlights the importance of certification in forested regions and the need for certification to be part of a broader effort to reduce deforestation.

The exocyst complex is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in the evolution of vertebrates, and the sex of an individual is often a defining characteristic of its phenotype. In many species, the sex of an individual is determined by a single genetic locus. In others, multiple genetic loci interact to determine sex. In this work, we show that the sex of a fish can be determined by a single locus in some populations, but by multiple interacting loci in others. We also show that the sex of a fish can be determined by multiple interacting loci in some populations, but by a single locus in others.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by a variety of free radicals, reactive oxygen species, and reactive carbonyl species. These species are generated by photochemistry, lipid peroxidation, and photodegradation of lipofuscin, a yellow pigment that accumulates in the retina. We show that the levels of iron in the retina, which is a key player in redox reactions, can influence the levels of lipofuscin. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of iron in the retina and may lead to the development of new therapies for the retina. (Show more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystem functioning, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is central to understanding the structure of food webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is difficult to evolve morphological and functional optimizations in separate structures. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, have evolved a modular prey-capture system, with specialized structures for different prey types. Our findings contribute to understanding the evolution of specialization, and the role of morphological innovation in shaping present-day food webs.

The human hand is a complex and highly specialized structure. The evolution of the human hand is a key topic in the study of human evolution. This study provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process.

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of both human serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) isozymes, which are both highly expressed in cancer. We show that this inhibitor is effective in inhibiting colon cancer xenograft growth, and that it is particularly effective in inhibiting B-cell lines. We also show that the inhibitor is defective in one of the most common forms of lymphoma, diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, this inhibitor has the potential to be a useful cancer therapeutic.

This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets. This is important because forests are often overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The results have implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Farm machinery is a key driver of modern agriculture, but its use has come at a cost to the soil. We show that the weight of modern farm machinery has increased by a factor of 10 since the 1960s, and that this increase has led to a shift in the distribution of stresses in the soil. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
